title: Camshaft - Removal

body.body: Make sure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported.
Do not support the motorcycle on any ancillary component, the exhaust system or any other non structural parts of the motorcycle frame.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
An unstable motorcycle may fall resulting in motorcycle damage, serious injury or death.
When turning the crankshaft at the front of the engine (clutch cover end) always turn anticlockwise.
When turning the crankshaft at the rear of the engine (alternator cover end) always turn clockwise.
Turning the crankshaft in the wrong direction may cause the camshaft drive chain to slip on the camshaft sprockets resulting in incorrect camshaft timing.
Remove the spark plugs to reduce compression resistance when turning the engine (see
Remove the crankshaft locking pin plug from the crankcase.
At the front of the engine, rotate the crankshaft anticlockwise using the bolt fitted to the end of the crankshaft so any two camshaft sprocket fixings are accessible.
The camshaft sprocket fixings need only be loosened sufficiently to allow the sprockets to rotate on the camshafts.
Loosen the two accessible camshaft sprocket fixings. Do not remove the fixings at this stage.
Rotate the crankshaft until the remaining two fixings are accessible.

Do not rotate the crankshaft further once the four camshaft sprocket bolts have been loosened. Rotation of the crankshaft with the four sprocket bolts loose will result in valve to piston contact and serious engine damage.
Loosen the two remaining camshaft sprocket fixings.
Note the orientation and position of the camshafts caps for installation.
Number the camshafts caps to make sure they are fitted to their original position and orientation.
Each camshaft cap has two hollow dowels fitted to them. Note their positions for installation.
Evenly and progressively release the bolts securing the camshaft caps to the cylinder head in the sequence shown below.
Remove the camshaft caps. Collect the dowels (if loose),
Lift the camshaft drive chain from the exhaust camshaft sprocket and remove the exhaust camshaft.
Repeat the procedure for the inlet camshaft.
Noting its orientation for installation remove the camshaft drive chain.
Remove the crankshaft locking pin plug from the crankcase.

At the front of the engine, rotate the crankshaft anticlockwise using the bolt fitted to the end of the crankshaft until the two gear teeth with an alignment mark on each is visible and central in the hole for the crankshaft locking pin.
The alignment mark on the flange of
is in line with the gear tooth at the other end of the service tool. Use this alignment mark as a guide when inserting the service tool.
through the hole in the crankcase. Make sure the gear tooth on the service tool fits between the two teeth with the alignment marks.
Note the orientation for each camshaft sprockets for installation.
Remove and discard the camshaft sprocket fixings.
Separate the camshafts from the sprockets.

Make sure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported.
Do not support the motorcycle on any ancillary component, the exhaust system or any other non structural parts of the motorcycle frame.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
An unstable motorcycle may fall resulting in motorcycle damage, serious injury or death.
When turning the crankshaft at the front of the engine (clutch cover end) always turn anticlockwise.
When turning the crankshaft at the rear of the engine (alternator cover end) always turn clockwise.
Turning the crankshaft in the wrong direction may cause the camshaft drive chain to slip on the camshaft sprockets resulting in incorrect camshaft timing.
Perform the following operations:
Seat - Removal
Battery - Removal
Fuel Tank - Removal
Clutch Cover - Removal
Plenum - Removal (All Markets Except US)
or
Plenum - Removal (US Markets Only)
Camshaft Cover - Removal
Remove the spark plugs to reduce compression resistance when turning the engine (see

Remove the crankshaft locking pin plug from the crankcase.
Locking pin plug
At the front of the engine, rotate the crankshaft anticlockwise using the bolt fitted to the end of the crankshaft so any two camshaft sprocket fixings are accessible.
The camshaft sprocket fixings need only be loosened sufficiently to allow the sprockets to rotate on the camshafts.
Loosen the two accessible camshaft sprocket fixings. Do not remove the fixings at this stage.
Fixings
Rotate the crankshaft until the remaining two fixings are accessible.

Do not rotate the crankshaft further once the four camshaft sprocket bolts have been loosened. Rotation of the crankshaft with the four sprocket bolts loose will result in valve to piston contact and serious engine damage.
Loosen the two remaining camshaft sprocket fixings.
Remove the camshaft drive tensioner (see
Camshaft Drive Chain Tensioner - Removal
Note the orientation and position of the camshafts caps for installation.
Number the camshafts caps to make sure they are fitted to their original position and orientation.
Each camshaft cap has two hollow dowels fitted to them. Note their positions for installation.
Evenly and progressively release the bolts securing the camshaft caps to the cylinder head in the sequence shown below.
Camshaft Caps Release Sequence
Remove the camshaft caps. Collect the dowels (if loose),
Dowel locations
Lift the camshaft drive chain from the exhaust camshaft sprocket and remove the exhaust camshaft.
Repeat the procedure for the inlet camshaft.
Noting its orientation for installation remove the camshaft drive chain.
Remove the crankshaft locking pin plug from the crankcase.

At the front of the engine, rotate the crankshaft anticlockwise using the bolt fitted to the end of the crankshaft until the two gear teeth with an alignment mark on each is visible and central in the hole for the crankshaft locking pin.
Crankshaft primary gear
Alignment marks
The alignment mark on the flange of
T3880501 - Crankshaft Locking Pin
is in line with the gear tooth at the other end of the service tool. Use this alignment mark as a guide when inserting the service tool.
Insert
service tool T3880501
through the hole in the crankcase. Make sure the gear tooth on the service tool fits between the two teeth with the alignment marks.
T3880501 - Crankshaft Locking Pin
Alignment mark
Note the orientation for each camshaft sprockets for installation.
Remove and discard the camshaft sprocket fixings.
Separate the camshafts from the sprockets.
